reviewText: This version deviates a lot from the book. I love watching Alan Ladd -his interpretation of Gatsby was good and the other actors are fine but the role of Daisy was not as strong, and that of the mechanic was not as I imagined. I have not seen the Redford version but I truly did enjoy the DiCaprio version except I did not agree with the director's choice of using contemporary music when there is a lot of good Jazz music from that era that could have been employed,
summary: It was just ok-it could have been better.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Alan Ladd has been overlooked a little in the acting department compared with his contemporaries.  He made many fine, interesting films and The Great Gatsby must be considered one of his finest portrayals. It's an interesting tale of a young man's desire to get on in the world in order to have the love of his life who has married some-one else.  The supporting cast is made up of well-known actors of the time and all do their roles with the expertise expected of these fine actors and actresses.  The film is well worth watching and I recommend it to both Alan Ladd fans and devotess of films of the past.Annette.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is adapted from the novel of the same title published in 1925 by F. Scott Fitzgerald.  It was preceded by a 1926 silent version and followed by 1974, 2000 and 2013 versions.  All versions differ from each other and are worth seeing, but are based on the same structure including a two men, one woman love triangle, a hit-and-run car accident killing the mistress of one of the men with disputes over who was driving and a murder of the other man with links to the car accident and disputes over the choice of the killer's target.  For more details on these matters, please see my review of The Great Gatsby 1974, and then consider my comparisons of the 1949 and 1974 versions that appear below as sufficient information to guide someone trying to decide whether to buy the 1949 version or not,Black & White versus color differences give the 1949 version more dramatic impact and less beauty than the 1974 version.  The plot is more explicitly stated and complete in the 1949 version, favoring viewers who want to know what is going on at all times.  The plot has more omissions, key information stated in a whisper or delayed revelations in the 1974 version, favoring those who want to be mystified for a time, with revelations falling together late.  The 1949 acting reveals people more like they probably were in the 1920s, with the loud staccato male voices and with rottenness selectively revealed as characteristics of individuals.  The 1974 acting reveals smoother, less forceful behavior patterns in men living farther the 1920s and rottenness distributed widely as an almost universal characteristic.
summary: Elliot Nugent Directs Alan Ladd, Betty Field, Barry Sullivan and Shelly Winters in 1949 Black & White Gem

reviewText: DeCaprio's portrayal was better than Redford's polished performance, precisely because it got at the heart of Gatsby's conflicted character and the tortured background he was trying to hide.Ladd's version is, in my judgment, the best of the three, because it was shot in black-and-white as a film noir, and because Ladd gives the perfect performance as the polished gangster (which barely comes out in either the Redford or DeCaprio version--you know by association that DeCaprio is a gangster, but he does not demonstrate gangster features.). Ladd, though polished in his carriage, does gangster-like stuff himself, like knocking out the guy from his past, Reba, who crashes his party and calls Gatsby "Gatz" (his real name from his poverty-stricken Dakotas past) in front of his guests and friends.So I have no idea why this film has such a low rating. Alan Ladd was one of America's best actors in the forties and fifties, and anyone who does not believe it should watch "Shane", which has been shown for decades to high-schoolers attempting capture the complexity of the book by that name and its central character. Ladd's performance in Gatsby is at least as good as his performance in "Shane".
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is in many ways more faithful to the book than the 1974 one. Ladd, although not a great actor, is a morebelievable Gatsby than Redford. Carey and Sullivan are fine in their respective roles of Carraway and Buchanan. The major weakness (as in the 74 version) was the casting of Daisy. Betty Field simply cannot carry the role. A pleasantsurprise was the casting of (a still svelte) Shelley Winters as Myrtle. She unfortunately does not get as much screen timeas Karen Black in the 74 film since the earlier movie skipped the party scene where Tom Buchanan broke Myrtle's nose. I now have to watch the most recent version for comparison.
summary: Solid Adaptation of a Classic Novel
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is considered, by some, as the best version. I agree and it is one of Alan Ladd's best performances of this classic tale. It is a drama, with little action. The Director kept the film short, with little extraneous nonsense. I think it is very well done.

reviewText: Ladd is still Gatsby to me.  Somehow I found his performance more real than either Redford's refinement or DiCaprio's psychosis.  This DVD preserves Ladd as well as can be expected until an actual studio release happens (which, at this point, is highly unlikely.)  I'm greatful to these  providers for the things that otherwise we'd be unable to get at any price.

reviewText: I now have all three versions and this is the best. Alan Ladd makes the best Gatsby. It does not blow-up the story with over-whelming sets and gimmicks. I am so glad to finally have this 1949 version that has never been available until now. We are so used to Blu-Ray, but this print is very good in the regular format. There is even a preview of the 1926 silent version.
summary: Finally, a good print of this never before seen 1949 version.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The 1949 "Gatsby" is a long buried classic that deserves the commercial video light of day. Produced by Paramount, it has been buried since it's release. The above reference to a Universal Home Video release is inaccurate, as Universal claims to not own the production rights. This film is haunting, and probably Ladd's finest dramatic performance. Macdonald Carey as Nick Carraway, is the moral conscience in a decadent time of any thing goes, as long as you win. NB: I recently encountered a commercial version of this film. It was released in 1980 by "Hollywood Home Theater," in a plastic clamshell case. The quality is very good - the best I've seen for this film. The problem is that this version is very rare and hard to find.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Alan Ladd was often dismissed as a one film wonder in Shane, but every so often he was allowed to break free and act against type. In The Great Gatsby, he plays the central role of Gatsby quite well. I under stand he really wanted the part and he deserved it.The problem is not Ladd, it is the rest of the film. The central character of Daisy is not well played and it is hard to see anyone throwing their life away on this woman. Some of the other characters are wooden and their interpretation is often stiff. The actor who plays Tom Buchanan just looks wrong. He should be a massive footballer, he looks like a tall thread of a man.The art direction is very good and the scenes with Ladd looking over the water at the East Egg building of Buchanan is very strong. I have no idea why this film is not on video,but Paramount seems a little slow in releasing their films for some reason.

reviewText: Under my watch this movie never was shown on TV, was never in the movies, never on Tape or DVD. Now I am ecstatic to have seen this very interesting take on the novel. It doesn;t just hint at the probability of Gatsby's past. It comes out and shows you the extent of his nefarious beginnings. Frankly, I now see the relationship between this story and Wuthering Heights. They are different in a lot of ways, but the basic theme is still the same. Outsider in love with the society woman, gains fame and fortune, returns to claim what he believes is his and tragedy ensues. I love it. The seller surpast all my expectations for this rare gem to land in my greedy little hands.
summary: Waiting for 50 years to see this movie.

reviewText: After seeing the newest Great Gatsby film in summer 2013, I was intrigued by the story and set out to obtain all prior renditions. I'm glad I did. This film provides a lot of perspective as to how Baz Luhrmann chose to shape his cast and backdrop for the most recent portrayal of this story. Of course, it's a great edition in itself. Alan Ladd, I can now see, was the perfect man for the role. I would recommend this movie to anyone.

reviewText: I'm grateful to  David C. Hearn's review, which prompted me to buy the Sky Chrom release. This is quite an acceptable print despite some image distortion as the camera scans sideways. Now, for the first time,  I can see clearly the boyish mix of anticipation and uncertainty on Alan Ladd's face as Gatsby is reunited with Daisy at Nick's place. This scene is so moving it brings tears to my eyes. Ladd was a good actor. I've seen most of the other Gatsbys, including the newest version, and to me Ladd's remains the only Great one.
